subject: Medicine
title: Ion Channels
description: A micro-lesson that makes Ion Channels usable.

hook.text: Local anesthetics block sodium channels in your nerves. No sodium flow means no pain signal. Simple and elegant.

buildup.text: Ion channels are gates in cell membranes that control the flow of charged particles like sodium and calcium.

discovery.text: Opening or closing these channels alters nerve signaling, muscle contraction, and heart rhythm.

twist.text: Pufferfish toxin blocks sodium channels so completely that it causes paralysis and death in minutes.

climax.text: Drugs targeting ion channels treat epilepsy, heart arrhythmias, pain, and high blood pressure.

quiz.question: How do local anesthetics prevent pain?
options: They block sodium channels so nerves cannot transmit pain signals
They destroy the nerve endings at the injection site
They flood the area with endorphins to mask pain
